description: Netdata dashboards for Grafana via Prometheus.

panels.description: Busy state of all CPU cores together
panels.title: CPU Busy

panels.description: Non available RAM memory
panels.title: Used RAM Memory

panels.description: Used Swap
panels.title: Used SWAP

panels.description: Used Root FS
panels.title: Used Root FS

panels.description: System uptime
panels.title: Uptime

panels.description: Total number of CPU cores
panels.title: CPU Cores

panels.description: Total RAM
panels.title: Total RAM

panels.description: Total SWAP
panels.title: Total SWAP

panels.description: Total RootFS
panels.title: Total RootFS

panels.description:
Total CPU utilization (all cores). 100% here means there is no CPU idle time at all. You can get per core usage at the _CPUs_ section and per application usage at the _Applications monitoring_ section.

Keep an eye on **iowait**. If it is constantly high, your disks are a bottleneck and they slow your system down.

An important metric worth monitoring, is **softirq**. A constantly high percentage of softirq may indicate network driver issues.
panels.title: Total CPU utilization

panels.description:
Current system load, i.e. the number of processes using CPU or waiting for system resources (usually CPU and disk). The 3 metrics refer to 1, 5 and 15 minute averages. The system calculates this once every 5 seconds.

For more information check this [Wikipedia article](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Load_(computing))
panels.title: System load average

panels.description:
Total Disk I/O, for all physical disks. You can get detailed information about each disk at the _Disks_ section and per application Disk usage at the _Applications Monitoring_ section.

Physical are all the disks that are listed in `/sys/block`, but do not exist in `/sys/devices/virtual/block`.
panels.title: Disk I/O

panels.description: Memory paged from/to disk. This is usually the total disk I/O of the system.
panels.title: Memory paged from/to disk

panels.description: System Random Access Memory (i.e. physical memory) usage.
panels.title: System RAM

panels.description: System swap memory usage. Swap space is used when the amount of physical memory (RAM) is full. When the system needs more memory resources and the RAM is full, inactive pages in memory are moved to the swap space (usually a disk, a disk partition or a file).
panels.title: System swap

panels.description: Total Swap I/O. (netdata measures both `in` and `out`. If either of them is not shown in the chart, it is because it is zero - you can change the page settings to always render all the available dimensions on all charts).
panels.title: Swap I/O

panels.description: Total IPv4 Traffic.
panels.title: IPv4 bandwidth

panels.description: Total IPv6 Traffic.
panels.title: IPv6 bandwidth

panels.description: System processes. **Running** are the processes in the CPU. **Blocked** are processes that are willing to enter the CPU, but they cannot, e.g. because they wait for disk activity.
panels.title: System processes

panels.description: Number of new processes created.
panels.title: Started processes

panels.description: All system processes.
panels.title: System active processes

panels.description: [Context Switches](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Context_switch), is the switching of the CPU from one process, task or thread to another. If there are many processes or threads willing to execute and very few CPU cores available to handle them, the system is making more context switching to balance the CPU resources among them. The whole process is computationally intensive. The more the context switches, the slower the system gets.
panels.title: CPU context switches

panels.description: Idle jitter is calculated by netdata. A thread is spawned that requests to sleep for a few microseconds. When the system wakes it up, it measures how many microseconds have passed. The difference between the requested and the actual duration of the sleep, is the idle jitter. This number is useful in real-time environments, where CPU jitter can affect the quality of the service (like VoIP media gateways).
panels.title: CPU idle jitter

panels.description: Total number of CPU interrupts. Check the system interrupts graph that gives more detail about each interrupt and also the _CPUs_ section where interrupts are analyzed per CPU core.
panels.title: CPU interrupts

panels.description: CPU interrupts in detail. At the _CPUs_ section, interrupts are analyzed per CPU core.
panels.title: System interrupts

panels.description: CPU softirqs in detail. At the _CPUs_ section, softirqs are analyzed per CPU core.
panels.title: System softirqs

panels.description:
Statistics for CPUs SoftIRQs related to network receive work.

Break down per CPU core can be found at _CPU / softnet statistics_. processed states the number of packets processed, dropped is the number packets dropped because the network device backlog was full (to fix them on Linux use `sysctl` to increase `net.core.netdev_max_backlog`), squeezed is the number of packets dropped because the network device budget ran out (to fix them on Linux use `sysctl` to increase `net.core.netdev_budget`).

More information about identifying and troubleshooting network driver related issues can be found at [Red Hat Enterprise Linux Network Performance Tuning Guide](https://access.redhat.com/sites/default/files/attachments/20150325_network_performance_tuning.pdf).
panels.title: System softnet_stat

panels.description:
[Entropy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Entropy_(computing)), is a pool of random numbers ([/dev/random](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki//dev/random)) that is mainly used in cryptography.

If the pool of entropy gets empty, processes requiring random numbers may run a lot slower (it depends on the interface each program uses), waiting for the pool to be replenished. Ideally a system with high entropy demands should have a hardware device for that purpose (TPM is one such device).

There are also several software-only options you may install, like `haveged`, although these are generally useful only in servers.
panels.title: Available entropy

panels.description: Available Memory is estimated by the kernel, as the amount of RAM that can be used by userspace processes, without causing swapping.
panels.title: Available RAM for applications

panels.description: Committed Memory, is the sum of all memory which has been allocated by processes.
panels.title: Committed (allocated) memory

panels.description:
A [page fault](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Page_fault) is a type of interrupt, called trap, raised by computer hardware when a running program accesses a memory page that is mapped into the virtual address space, but not actually loaded into main memory.

If the page is loaded in memory at the time the fault is generated, but is not marked in the memory management unit as being loaded in memory, then it is called a minor or soft page fault.

A major page fault is generated when the system needs to load the memory page from disk or swap memory.
panels.title: Memory page faults

panels.description: **Dirty** is the amount of memory waiting to be written to disk. **Writeback** is how much memory is actively being written to disk.
panels.title: Writeback memory

panels.description: The total amount of memory being used by the kernel. **Slab** is the amount of memory used by the kernel to cache data structures for its own use. **KernelStack** is the amount of memory allocated for each task done by the kernel. **PageTables** is the amount of memory decicated to the lowest level of page tables (A page table is used to turn a virtual address into a physical memory address). **VmallocUsed** is the amount of memory being used as virtual address space.
panels.title: Memory used by kernel

panels.description: **Reclaimable** is the amount of memory which the kernel can reuse. **Unreclaimable** can not be reused even when the kernel is lacking memory.
panels.title: Reclaimable kernel memory

panels.description: Amount of data transferred to and from disk.
panels.title: Disk I/O bandwidth

panels.description: Completed disk I/O operations. Keep in mind the number of operations requested might be higher, since the system is able to merge adjacent to each other (see merged operations chart).
panels.title: Disk completed I/O operations

panels.description: I/O operations currently in progress. This metric is a snapshot - it is not an average over the last interval.
panels.title: Disk current I/O operations

panels.description: Backlog is an indication of the duration of pending disk operations. On every I/O event the system is multiplying the time spent doing I/O since the last update of this field with the number of pending operations. While not accurate, this metric can provide an indication of the expected completion time of the operations in progress.
panels.title: Disk backlog

panels.description:
Disk Utilization measures the amount of time the disk was busy with something. This is not related to its performance. 100% means that the system always had an outstanding operation on the disk.

Keep in mind that depending on the underlying technology of the disk, 100% here may or may not be an indication of congestion.
panels.title: Disk utilization time

panels.description: The average time for I/O requests issued to the device to be served. This includes the time spent by the requests in queue and the time spent servicing them.
panels.title: Average completed I/O operation time

panels.description: The average I/O operation size.
panels.title: Average completed I/O operation bandwidth

panels.description: The average service time for completed I/O operations. This metric is calculated using the total busy time of the disk and the number of completed operations. If the disk is able to execute multiple parallel operations the reporting average service time will be misleading.
panels.title: Average service time

panels.description: The number of merged disk operations. The system is able to merge adjacent I/O operations, for example two 4KB reads can become one 8KB read before given to disk.
panels.title: Disk merged operations

panels.description: The sum of the duration of all completed I/O operations. This number can exceed the interval if the disk is able to execute I/O operations in parallel.
panels.title: Disk total I/O time

panels.description: Disk space utilization. reserved for root is automatically reserved by the system to prevent the root user from getting out of space.
panels.title: Disk space usage

panels.description:
inodes (or index nodes) are filesystem objects (e.g. files and directories).

On many types of file system implementations, the maximum number of inodes is fixed at filesystem creation, limiting the maximum number of files the filesystem can hold. It is possible for a device to run out of inodes.

When this happens, new files cannot be created on the device, even though there may be free space available.
panels.title: Disk files (inodes) usage

panels.description: UDMA CRC Error Count (smartd_log.udma_crc_error_count)
panels.title: S.M.A.R.T external failure

panels.description: UDMA CRC Error Count (smartd_log.udma_crc_error_count)
panels.title: S.M.A.R.T external failure

panels.description: Start/Stop Count (smartd_log.start_stop_count)
panels.title: S.M.A.R.T power cycles

panels.description: Power-On Hours Count (smartd_log.power_on_hours_count)
panels.title: S.M.A.R.T Power-On Hours

panels.description: Temperature (smartd_log.temperature_celsius)
panels.title: S.M.A.R.T temperature

panels.description: The number of established TCP connections (known as `CurrEstab`). This is a snapshot of the established connections at the time of measurement (i.e. a connection established and a connection disconnected within the same iteration will not affect this metric).
panels.title: IPv4 TCP connections

panels.description: **active** or `ActiveOpens` is the number of outgoing TCP **connections attempted** by this host. **passive** or `PassiveOpens` is the number of incoming TCP **connections accepted** by this host.
panels.title: IPv4 TCP opens

panels.description: `InErrs` is the number of TCP segments received in error (including header too small, checksum errors, sequence errors, bad packets - for both IPv4 and IPv6). `InCsumErrors` is the number of TCP segments received with checksum errors (for both IPv4 and IPv6). `RetransSegs` is the number of TCP segments retransmitted.
panels.title: IPv4 TCP errors

panels.description:
TCP connection errors.

**baddata** (`TCPAbortOnData`) happens while the connection is on `FIN_WAIT1` and the kernel receives a packet with a sequence number beyond the last one for this connection - the kernel responds with `RST` (closes the connection).

**userclosed** (`TCPAbortOnClose`) happens when the kernel receives data on an already closed connection and responds with `RST`.

**nomemory** (`TCPAbortOnMemory` happens when there are too many orphaned sockets (not attached to an fd) and the kernel has to drop a connection - sometimes it will send an `RST`, sometimes it won't.

**timeout** (`TCPAbortOnTimeout`) happens when a connection times out.

**linger** (`TCPAbortOnLinger`) happens when the kernel killed a socket that was already closed by the application and lingered around for long enough.

**failed** (`TCPAbortFailed`) happens when the kernel attempted to send an `RST` but failed because there was no memory available.
panels.title: TCP connection errors

panels.description:
`EstabResets` is the number of established connections resets (i.e. connections that made a direct transition from `ESTABLISHED` or `CLOSE_WAIT` to `CLOSED`).

`OutRsts` is the number of TCP segments sent, with the `RST` flag set (for both IPv4 and IPv6).

`AttemptFails` is the number of times TCP connections made a direct transition from either `SYN_SENT` or `SYN_RECV` to `CLOSED`, plus the number of times TCP connections made a direct transition from the `SYN_RECV` to `LISTEN`.

`TCPSynRetrans` shows retries for new outbound TCP connections, which can indicate general connectivity issues or backlog on the remote host.
panels.title: IPv4 TCP handshake issues
TCP reordered packets by detection method

panels.description:
[Explicit Congestion Notification (ECN)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Explicit_Congestion_Notification) is a TCP extension that allows end-to-end notification of network congestion without dropping packets.

ECN is an optional feature that may be used between two ECN-enabled endpoints when the underlying network infrastructure also supports it.
panels.title: IP ECN statistics

panels.description: Real memory (RAM) used by applications. This does not include shared memory.
panels.title: Real memory (w/o shared)

panels.description: Virtual memory allocated by applications. Please check [this article](https://github.com/firehol/netdata/wiki/netdata-virtual-memory-size) for more information.
panels.title: Virtual memory

title: netdata
